SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the Person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces or answers. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (✓) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

✓ All questionnaires will try to answer all questions.

✓ Pioneer health conditions
✓ Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
✓ Pioneer housing
✓ Pioneer education and churchwork
✓ Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: CATHERINE M. DOYLE
2. Your address: L.E. RAY, SASK.
3. Date: MAY
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) MANITOBA
5. What was your father's name and occupation? WM. KRAUS, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) JULY 1906
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child")
   I was in my second year, 1895, 16 years 9 months.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   My parents came in April 1906 and were convinced to stay by a friend who was coming to Yorkton as we were together to Winnipeg a few months earlier.

My family had a friend in New Mexico who heard about Manuretta. He came to Manuretta and learned about the climate and decided to move there. He came home to Manuretta N.W. He encouraged my Father and Mother to come also, so my Father and Mother came to Manuretta in May 1905 and found out that it was a good place to live.
PIONEER HISTORY QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: CATHERINE M. DOYLE, L.E.
2. Your address: 4 E. RAY, SASK.
3. Date: MAY 1906.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) MANITOBA, CANADA.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? WM. KRAUS, FARMER.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? JULY 1906.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Weyburn, Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you were under 18 years old at that time.)
   I was 16 years old in 1906.

9. What were your reasons for coming here?

My parents came in April 1906 and I was encouraged to come by a friend who was coming to Yorkton and we came together to Weyburn.

10. How did you travel to Weyburn?

My father had a friend named Mr. Smith who lived in Weyburn and he came to Manitoba and talked about Weyburn. He came to Weyburn and encouraged my family to come to Weyburn. We came to Weyburn in May 1906.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They did not like the idea, thought it was too far north and we would get lost and I lost weight.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With a friend & two small children to Winnipeg, then met in with a mail coming to Minnedosa & by railroad all the way from Minnedosa to Mennonite Beach.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Railroad all the way from Minnedosa to Mennonite Beach.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

We met two boys who had went to Kansas college within the North, N.W. during the winter of 1906 when we came to the border town they heard me & had a boat both at U.A. and David, when shipped friend who I met and I got to Minnedosa by train and into town to meet us, as my family had asked him to meet new homes dark and raining then arrived to be no platform as we fell in what we called a ditch.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Stayed the first night in Minnedosa N.W. and next day returned to the homestead where my parents, father & children lived.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Homestead Town in 1906 near Minnedosa.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

From July 1906 to 1922. N.E. 1/4 Sect 10 Town 36 Rg 21

From April 1922 to Nov 1948 N.E. 8 1/4 Sect 11 Town 35 Rg 21

Two years stayed with relatives.

Living in Kellard since April 1950.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Want to submit before coming to Canada.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
They did not like the idea, thought it was too far north and we would get lost and die.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
With a friend & two small children to Winnipeg, then met in with a girl coming to Prince Albert by train.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
Railroad all the way from Montreal N.D.U. to Prince Albert.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)
I met two boys who had went to farm college within three months. During the winter of 1906 when we came to the border they heard us to have a boat load at U.A. and a third. When I got to Prince Albert I met a friend who I met and I got to Prince Albert by train. We then traveled to Prince Albert by train. We met my mother dark and raining. She arrived at the next station so we fell into what we called a ditch.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
Stayed the first night in Prince Albert and next day returned to the homestead under my parents, further west.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
Mama & I toured in 1906 to Prince Albert.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
From July 1906 to 1922. In 1922 to 1948. From April 1948 to Nov 1948. Living in Regina with relatives.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
I went to school before coming to Canada.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Very often she wrote at least once a month.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

ANDREW M. ROYLT, April 26, 1922

Married at St. Patrick Church, Oat Hill, Mass.

21. Did anyone else come to settle?

A number came in account from Fall River.

My two sisters and my brother came with my parents in May 1906 and settled on N. E. Lot 10 Town 35 Range 21 W 2nd.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came first tell when they came and where they settled.

23. In three particular experiences of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to recount:

A sad experience happened in July-August 1906, after and his wife and two girls were always friendly and kind and not harsh or cruel. They were very hardworking families, three in the house and yet there was never any lack of food or clothing.

One Sunday in October 1907 just when the snow was going down, the wind was blowing a gale up a tree. My father was hard at work trying to get the tree down. He fell down, and the wind kept blowing until he was buried under the tree.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, visiting friends, etc.)

No, we traveled very little by what means of travel.

25. Visiting friends, etc.

Only two times was necessary, attended church and visited neighbors in summer and winter. Would play cards or games or visit friends. Winter was very cold and snowy. We had to go out to get our supplies and horses and sleds in winter. How did the neighbors travel by overland trail?

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1921? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, many moved away. Some moved west first because too much work in hard work to buck land and third too backward, thought it was too hard to make a home.

My father was trustee on school board from 1908 until his death in 1942. He was also trustee on church until his death in 1942. He was also church president and was secretary of the P.T.A. in church from 1907 until 1950 when it was dissolved.

Yes, my parents moved away. They moved away because there was not enough land and too much work to be done on the farm. They thought it was too hard to make a living.

Yes many moved away. One reason was first second too much brush and too hard work to buck land and third too backward. Thought it was too hard to make a home.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My Father was trustee on school board from 1908 until his death in 1942. He was also trustee on church & director on telephone. My Husband was trustee on church & school for 20 years. I was secretary at St. Patrick's Church from 1907 until 1950 when I moved to Leloy. I was secretary treasurer for North Lancing Rural Telephone Co. 1933

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Give facts of new name as above in (2), (3), (5).

Our school was built in 1908 and was named after Father Simnett. (Simnett S.D. 1809) and was changed to Manuel S.D. 1809 in the year 1916. Our post office was named M.E. Simnett because it was at M.E. Simnett House, N.E. 1st 2 Towns 35 Range 21 but later on was moved to my Father's place N.E. 1st 10 Towns 35 Range 21. We tried to name it Manuel after our town but the government named it Manuel when Leloy became a town our post office was closed so we all got mail at Leloy. Leloy was named after Jack Leloy, a soldier killed in World War I.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1940? They have not moved away. Our nearest was from back land and child to backland, though it was too hard to make a home.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices or have been active in any organizations, mention it here giving dates when possible.

My family was active in church and also active in church until the late 1940s. We were also active in church from 1967 until our family moved to Idaho.

37. If you or any of your family or friends have ever served as president of any organization, mention it here (if possible).

I am not sure if my family has ever served as president of any organization.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, etc.)

The town was named after my father, John T. (Simmons). It was named in the year 1910 because it was at the time of its formation. The date and reason for its name are unknown.

39. Any other interesting facts about your community?

Our town became a town in 1910 but the government named it Monroe County. It was named after my father, John T. (Simmons). It was named in the year 1910 because it was at the time of its formation. The date and reason for its name are unknown.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

One good thing was the dugouts as the farmers could keep cattle & hogs and I think the bush cutters were wonderful as the farmers who could get some cash could get bush cut then finish the land and raise crops. Homesteads that was all poplar groves are now wheat & grain fields.

41. What do you think are the most important changes to your community since you first came here?

Our grandparents didn't have the opportunity to go to school. They could only read and write, which made it difficult for them to get jobs. Our parents got better jobs because they could read and write. Now our children can attend better schools and have more opportunities.
